meeting_annotations.transcript: I don't necessarily know if there are, they, we have a lot of meetings, but I don't know if there's really a good meeting that, like if you think about the North American Catalysis Society meeting, which is the biggest meeting in the heterogeneous world, like electrocatalysis is hardly welcome there. Uh, and then, you know, ECS, um, uh, you know, I think generally doesn't have too much heterogeneous catalysis. So, so I think there's not, it's not clear that there's an easy bridge, uh, to be, to be formed. meeting_annotations.speaker: WS
meeting_annotations.transcript: Adding on to that is, you know, I don't think it's a matter of why can't we do certain things. I think it's directly a matter of the competition. There are already existing processes that are large scale that have a very cheap feed stock and relatively efficiently and stably can make something. So it's not that we can't make, it's not that we're trying to make some product that's never been made before. The problem is the competition. It is so cheap and so large scale already that are, I mean, it's, you know, I agree. I mean, there's not a thermodynamic or fundamental scientific reason we can't do these things, but in terms of cost, I mean, even if we throw a billion dollars at it, it's still going to be way cheaper for Shell or Exxon to continue what they're doing, pay their carbon taxes and they will be just fine financially, which is, you know, we have to remind ourselves of business is involved in this. So I think that the biggest issue is that we're competing with existing technologies that have been around for a long time or large scale and very, very cheap and efficient.
